guide.introduction_rendered:
Relevant parts
  • Audio cable
  • Speaker, small 8Ω
  • Cheap MP3 Player
  • small neodymium magnets
Tools
  • File
  • Hot Glue gun & hot glue
  • Solder
  • Soldering iron

lines.text: Cut about 10cm off of the audio cable, then strip the wire as in the picture. For wires that are coated with enamel, use a file to scrape the enamel off. Solder the wires to the solder tabs on the speaker.
lines.text_raw: Cut about 10cm off of the audio cable, then strip the wire as in the picture. For wires that are coated with enamel, use a file to scrape the enamel off. Solder the wires to the solder tabs on the speaker.

lines.text: Take the neodymium magnet and use some hot glue to glue it on the edge of the speaker as in the picture.
lines.text_raw: Take the neodymium magnet and use some hot glue to glue it on the edge of the speaker as in the picture.

lines.text: Glue the other neodymium magnet to the glasses. Make sure the magnets won't repel each other.
lines.text_raw: Glue the other neodymium magnet to the glasses. Make sure the magnets won't repel each other.

lines.text: Plug the audio cable into the MP3 player's stereo jack. Then clip the MP3 player onto the glasses and attach the speaker to the glasses.
lines.text_raw: Plug the audio cable into the MP3 player's stereo jack. Then clip the MP3 player onto the glasses and attach the speaker to the glasses.

guide.summary: Make a speaker that will attach to glasses or sunglasses.
guide.title: Speaker That Attaches to Glasses
